comments:
I dropped the manifest.mf that Pascal posted to eclipse-dev into the 
core.runtime.compatibility plugin of build I-20040225.

I shut down and restarted, and I got the NPE pasted below but my workbench 
still came up.
I shut down and replaced Pascal's manifest.mf with the original one and 
restarted it.  The workbench did not start.
I killed the process and deleted my config area.  I was then able to start.

*** Bug 53154 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The problem is related to some plugins having
org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility *optionally* required (core.expressions,
text). Other plugins also optionally require compatibility, but at least one of
the plugins in their required list requires compatibility (mandatorily).

So:
- they fail to be started, because their bundle activator class is not available
(they don't get the one from core.runtime.compatibility)
- their classes are available to plugins requiring them, but since the the
plugin object was not instantiated, some funny things (like a NPE doing
XYZPlugin.getDefault().doSomething(), because getDefault() returns null)

Note: the ClassNotFoundExceptions (embedded in BundleExceptions) when trying to
activate bundles whose plugin activator is not available are being output to the
console instead of being logged.

One issue that has not been explained yet is how changing bundle manifests is
preventing Eclipse from starting.
what is the status of this?

The problem with the ExpressionPlugin is explained in comment 2 (wrong usage of
optional import). Plugin owners where notified. The code for detecting changes
to plugin/bundle manifests has changed a lot (the default case now is not to do
any checking). See bug 55390 and friends.
Just to make it clear, this is reproducible on recent builds.

sigh... 

I meant: this is *not* reproducible on recent builds...
